newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Anglo, De Beers in Zaire again to see rebels.
newsitem.headline: Anglo, De Beers in Zaire again to see rebels.

text.p: Senior executives of South Africa's Anglo American Corp and De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd were on their third visit to Zaire on Monday in less than a month to talk with Zaire's rebels.
Anglo spokeswoman Charmane Russell said officials from Anglo and its sister company De Beers left for Goma on Sunday to hold talks with Zairean rebel leader Laurent Kabila's AFDL.
"Anglo and De Beers officials are meeting (the rebels) in Goma. We started the dialogue two weeks ago and it is a continuation of that," Russell said.
She later said the officials would travel on to Zaire's second city and diamond centre of Lubumbashi. "They probably have gone on to Lubumbashi".
"Obviously Anglo still has a watching brief in Zaire, we still have one tender outstanding. We are keeping in contact with what is happening in Zaire," she said.
The visit is the third by Anglo and De Beers officials in less than a month, she added.
Anglo submitted two tenders for the development of Zaire's Kolwezi copper/cobalt talings project and another copper project at Ruashi-Etiole near Zaire's copper capital Lubumbashi.

The Kolwezi project was last week awarded by Kabila's rebels to U.S-based America Mineral Fields Inc (AMF) in a $1 billion deal which also included the planned construction of a 200,000 tonne/year zinc smelter at Kipushi.
Russel said Anglo had no knowledge of reports that the tender for Kolwezi was won by AMF in December.

"We dispute that. We say that as far as we are concerned that certainly is not the case. In fact all parties were invited to re-submit their tenders and the final tenders went in again on April 2," she said.

The embattled government of Zairean President Mobutu Sese Seko said last Thursday that it was annulling all contracts between Zaire's state-owned Gecamines (Generale de Carriers et des Mines) and AMF because AMF had "violated the regulations governing the signing of mining contracts and conventions".
Waging a rebellion against Mobutu's government for six months now, Kabila's AFDL is in control of more than half of Zaire including all mineral-producing areas.
An agreement between AMF and Anglo to jointly develop the Kolwezi project, was cancelled earlier this year.
De Beers held a contract with Mobutu's government to buy the production of state diamond company Societe Miniere de Bakwanga (MIBA) and also maintained five diamond buying offices throughout Zaire.

De Beers -- which controls the world diamond trade through the London-based Central Selling Organisation -- pulled staff out of Kisangani in December and from the diamond capital Mbuji-Mayi a few weeks ago.
